Carved into the face of a granite mountain itself, the prestigious school of sumo served all the needs the Rikishi and their fans could ever desire. A feasting hall more grand than even Bowser's own dining chambers, several sparring arenas, a sumo stable officiated by the worlds greatest sumo wrestlers.

"How exciting." Tanzo replied. "Though you are much bigger in person, I must admit."

"Yeah I put on some weight lately." Bowser patted his soft middle.

"Get used to it my friend." Said Tanzo. "You are quite thin compared to most of our esteemed Rikishi. Something that will change very quickly."

"How fast are we talking?" Bowser said. Thoughts of god-hood swam about his mind. The sooner the better.

Tanzo chuckled and led Bowser to a small counter. He reached his plump paws into a cabinet and fished about. Seconds later he plopped a thick binder on the counter and beckoned for Bowser to come forward. He opened it to reveal several "before-and-after" photos.

People of all shapes and sizes came to the Academy in different sizes. Tall, fat, short, thin, somewhere in between. They all came out much the same. Three months of training and these people became massive sumo wrestlers. Tanzo flipped to a specific page and pointed a familiar looking blue dragon.

"That is myself three months ago."

Bowser shook his head in disbelief. The blue dragon in the before picture was, to put it bluntly, quite puny. Gangly limbs without an ounce of muscle on them, and the only fat appeared to be a slight paunch on his stomach.

"You're kidding." Bowser turned to the fat dragon. "You could eat that scrawny thing three times over and still have room for more."

"Well I'm more than ready to go." Said Bowser. "When's dinner?"

"You must perform your workout routine first." Tanzo replied. "Then you may have dinner."

"What? Working out?" Bowser said. "That's a little...counter-intuitive isn't it?"

Tanzo smiled politely. "It may sound that way, but do not worry. Your body will greedily store those calories if it is starving. And to starve it, you must work it."

"If you say so."

"I know so! And I have the body to prove it." Tanzo replied. "Now come with me to the exercise room and we can begin your first day of training."

***

Sweat pearled upon Bowser's forehead and rolled down his fat cheeks. Breath escaped him faster than he could take it in. One more stomp and I'll die, Bowser thought. He strained to lift his meaty leg into the air, the squat burned his lower-back and glutes. Stomp.

"Oh my, we have much work to do." Tanzo said.

"Okay I admit I'm a little out of shape." Bowser huffed.

"Not to be too caustic, but I do not think there is anything little about you."

"I'll pretend I didn't hear that." Said Bowser. "Can't we go back to the weight bench again? I'm good at that."

He did not want to admit it, but lifting heavy plates of food to his greedy maw for the past year kept his chest and arms in some respectable shape. Even underneath layers of blubber. Even if they weren't as strong as they had always been.

"You must challenge yourself. Otherwise you will not improve." Said Tanzo. "Unless you intend to walk on your hands, I suggest these stomping exercises. You will be thankful when you reach the bigger sizes."

And back to stomping he went.

***
How wonderful, to sit and not stomp. To lift ounces with his arms, rather than pounds. To take in sweet, hot, smells with each breath. Dinner never quite tasted so good. Whatever it was.

"I'm going to quit tomorrow, I can just hit 3000 pounds eating." Bowser mumbled between mouthfuls. "Oh stars this is good."

But then he looked up from his bowl. Sumos of all ranks and sizes surrounded him. He could tell the newbies from the veterans instantly. And the veterans were huge. Massive piles of muscle and fat that horked down their food with zeal. Gluttons and proud of it.

Keep with it, Tanzo said, and he could be like them.

No need for a throne, his own backside served well enough. Never having to worry about exercise, or getting full. Just devouring and reigning king over those who devoured.

To be the god of the sumos, and the fat kids at school, the college student and their freshman 40, the buffet junky that takes of two seats alone. All his quarry. all his servants. Like his father always said, dream big.

"I just need to stick with it."

And so he gorged on every last bite. Plates of food disappeared while he relished the very act of eating. Something he found solace in for so long would prove to reward him in the end. Tsunami, they cheered from their seats.

Smash!

Dragon and koopa collided hard enough to split atoms. Bowser's entire lower body wobbled. Pain never bothered him. Years of being thrown into lava, explosives, or having castles collapse on him proved that. This became unlike anything he ever experienced. Like trying to stop a Tsunami with his clawed hands.

To achieve god-hood, he would have to best such forces of nature. To do things no other mortal could do. He was Hercules and this was one of his many trials.

Tenzo's concentration turned to astonishment the moment he felt his entire body fall back. Bowser managed to muster enough strength to push him back an inch. Then another, and finally two more inches. Four inches, he moved a Tsunami back four inches.

"Yes. But then I discovered my other passion." Said Tenzo. "Sumo is something that came natural to me. So when I became much bigger, even more than my own father, well, I stayed here for awhile longer."

Bowser beamed and nodded. A decent start for the first morning of training. They trudged a few feet further in the snow and approached a staircase. Massive stone cut and fit by hand. Bowser noticed every few steps presented a unique etching. A written character he did not recognize.

"What's with the writing?"

One step after the other Bowser and Takeshi scaled the staircase. His clawed toes kept traction on the iced steps. One misstep might send him tumbling to the bottom, he pressed on. The idea of a sumo society burned in the back of his mind. Perhaps the old god of gluttony imbued his family with such a lifestyle.

At the very top, Bowser found himself standing before several stone structures. They looked to be houses of some sort. Save for huge stone doors no one could move on their own. Takeshi approached one such residence and pulled a switch.

Nothing happened for a moment, then a distinct booming sound. Bowser recognized it from the academy. He heard the rumbling of Headmaster Taiho's footsteps from a room away. These felt no different.

The sound of stone grinding against itself filled the air. Bowser took a step back while the massive stone door slid to the side. A single, massive wolf tugged it over with ease. Bowser gulped. The family still lived there in the village.

"Takeshi!' The wolf spoke. "So it is true, you have returned."

"Yes, getting the best of the 'Kings' proved a little difficult on my own."

The elder wolf gave him a thoughtful look then nodded.

"I see, so you are recruiting then?"

"Yes I am." Takeshi replied.

"If I am not mistaken, this one is much too small."

Bowser fought hard to keep his mouth shut. He doubled the weight of his average species in the short space of a few months. How dare they talk down to him. Then, the elder wolf walked next to Bowser. His full height towered over the royal koopa, much like the Taiho family. His arms looked thicker than Bowser's neck. This specimen of wolf may well be a ton.

"He is not an official recruit." Takeshi said. "Not yet at least."

"Ah, you hope to shape him up."

"I see some potential in this one. Yes." Said Takeshi. "It just needs a small push to be realized."

Without his condescending tone, Takeshi almost resembled his father. It seemed sincere, the way he spoke of Bowser. The koopa realized the weight of this trust when the elder wolf objected.

"I do not suggest training an outsider in this manner. Our ways, are ours."

"And do you think I know nothing of Tenzo?"

The wolf became silent at that. Bowser tilted his head and raised his brow. What about Tenzo?

"Impressive as he is, the moment I saw him I knew he had your mark Aki." Takeshi said. "He has trained with you, and that is how he grew so big so fast."

"I saw his potential and it needed to be realized."

"And that is what I see in this one here. So please, let us in and we shall discuss the treatment of outsiders later."

Aki the wolf stepped aside and let them both in. He eyeballed Bowser for a second, perhaps trying to see what Takeshi saw in him. Then he shut the door.

"So when does training begin?" Bowser said beneath his breath.

"You're eager, not a bad trait." Takeshi chuckled. "I need to sort some things out with the village elders before we begin anything officially. I would say the trek here is your training for the day. Dinner is soon, and perhaps that too might be an exercise on its own."

Bowser bit his bottom lip and then looked around himself.

"Did you mean those things you said? About my potential?"

"I'm many things and a liar is not one of them."

"Why this change of heart? The other day you thought I was a waste of training."

"I forget you are known for being quite forward." Takeshi replied. "Let's just say that my brother Largo reminded me of a story. One about a young wolf whose arrogance made many enemies and lost many battles. All he needed was some humility and a push to make him great."

Bowser nodded and followed Takeshi further. He asked no more questions. He just hoped dinner was filling.

The council of elders had seen many winters, Bowser figured. A few of them could not rise to their feet on their own without the assistance of another younger wolf. Sometimes two or three wolves. Too frail to train, but not too frail to eat. Bowser looked to his own plate, loaded with steaming hot piles of meat, berries, and a bowl of stew.

"To just agree to your training, even on Takeshi's word, is too much." Said one member, between mouthfuls of a stew. "To dine with us as a guest is almost an insult."

"Don't be so hasty, you are so hesitant of these outsiders. Even the ones who are so open to our lifestyle." Said another, he must have been younger, for he could still stand on his own.

"Yes, but I get a feeling that you, Bowser Koopa, are here with bad intent." Said the first member. "Everyone knows the stories, of your attempted conquests of the mushroom kingdom. If we train you, what is stopping you from attacking us next?"

Takeshi began to speak, but Bowser opened his mouth too soon.

"I realize my past, and it's not something I'm too proud of. It's true, I joined sumo to try and gain an advantage, but it has made me see the error of my ways along the way. I want this to be my new life now, to forget my mistakes and try something better."

The council mumbled and then looked to Bowser.

"You must understand us, when we doubt the validity of such a statement." Said one elder. "You have never been known for truths."

"But, perhaps you may be able to prove it to us."

"We have a proposal for you, Bowser Koopa. One that will prove your dedication to sumo."

"I'm listening." Bowser leaned forward with interest.

"We will allow Takeshi to train you, on the condition that you make sumo a tradition in your home. Just as we have done here."

Bowser's thoughts instantly flashed to Junior, even Clawdia and his closest subjects. They might reject such a notion outright. He sighed and looked at the council.

"Okay, I'll try."

"Indeed you will."

"You will send a message home tonight."

"Tomorrow you will have your response, we are certain."

"And when you get your answer, you will either train here, or leave."

Bowser gulped and nodded.

He inhaled deep, and took stance. His half-ton girth felt weightless in the moment. Adrenaline surged through his veins.

His opponent took position across from him. The beast stomped the ground. Bowser swore a small crack formed in the clay arena.

Time slowed to a crawl. Bowser's heart pounded in his ears. The beast took off. A mighty wall of sumo came hurtling towards him. Bowser hesitated. A mistake on his part.

Over a thousand pounds of rikishi smashed into him. Powerful arms snared him by the shoulders and began to pull him to the side. Bowser's muscles throbbed and seized in an attempt to fight back. His right foot rose from the ground.

No, not today. Not here. Not now.

Bowser slammed his foot back down and struck the beast in the chest with an open palm strike. A thick slap drew a pained gasp from the opposing rikishi. Meaty pecs quivered while he stumbled back. Bowser charged forward, ready to seal his advantage.

He tried to snag his opponent's shoulders, when the reeling rikishi sprung back into action with surprising speed. The beast grabbed Bowser's arms and threw down.

Bowser felt his left leg give out beneath him while his momentum took a downward shift. Months of training, of practice, and his overzealous sumo strategies would prove him the loser. The image of him stuck at a thousand pounds, no way to move up without Takeshi's help.

He roared and struggled, a vague hope that his fury might break the beast's grip. Then, an opening. His arm broke free from his opponent's grasp with only milliseconds of time to turn the tide of the battle. Bowser hooked his free arm around the beast's side, Bowser's face pressed into its belly.

With one powerful shove of his foot, his falling moment swept the beast off its feet.

Bowser and his opponent entered free fall. The crowd screamed to life. Their voices muddled behind a wall of concentration. Bowser snarled, and tried to force the other rikishi to hit the ground first. He clenched his eyes tight and rolled his weight as best he could.

Bowser hit the ground with a dull rumble. A sharp pain seared his shoulder. The clay ground cracked open at his force.

It was over, and he had no idea if he won.

The two rikishi stumbled to their feet. A strain due in part to low gravity centers. Bowser's monstrous gut brushed against the ground while he shoved himself up. He looked to his shoulder and saw a raw scrape and the tender black flesh of a bruise. A small crater where Bowser's shoulder smashed the ground.

He looked to his fellow teammates. Their eyes ranged from stern, to sad. He lost. He hit the ground first.

"Replay the clip." A judge called out.

A huge screen above the arena flashed to life. Bowser's struggle flashed before his eyes. To see himself on screen gave him shivers. What felt like hours of fighting did not even translate to a minute of replay time. Then, the moment of truth.

The two fell into free fall. Bowser held his breath. He watched his shoulder. He scrutinized it. He cursed it.

"Stop the footage."

Bowser snapped to attention. His head dizzy from breaking his concentration. A yellow circle appeared on the screen. His opponent's fat hip brushed against the ground, with Bowser's shoulder mere centimeters away from the ground.

"Koopzilla takes the victory."

Bowser nearly fainted there on stage.
